headline: Chocolate Pudding Cake
description: Double your chocolate with this easy chocolate cake—it forms a cake layer and a decadent pudding layer as it bakes. It’s the chocolatey retro dessert recipe you’ll want to make again and again.
name: Chocolate Pudding Cake

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 350°F.  Lightly grease an 8x8-inch high-walled (at least 1 1/2 inches tall) cake pan or baking dish.

Make the first layer: In a large mixing bowl, make the first layer. Whisk together the flour, sugar, cocoa powder, baking powder, and salt. Using a wooden spoon or spatula, mix in the oil, milk, and vanilla extract until just combined. Transfer the batter to the prepared baking dish.

Add the second layer: In a small bowl, combine the brown sugar, granulated sugar, cocoa powder, and salt for the second layer. Use a fork to mix until combined and free of clumps. Sprinkle the mixture evenly over the cake batter. Sprinkle with mini chocolate chips, if using. Pour the hot coffee evenly all over the top. Do not stir .

Bake the cake: Bake the cake until it starts to pull away from the sides of the baking dish, 30 to 35 minutes. The top will have a crackly appearance. Remove the cake from the oven and allow it to cool slightly and set for 15 to 20 minutes before serving.  Scoop each serving with a large spoon, flipping it as you transfer it into a bowl or on a plate. This will allow for the pudding layer to be on top. Serve the cake on its own or dish it up with a scoop of ice cream or whipped cream.  Store leftover cake covered or in an airtight container in the fridge for up to 5 days. Reheat the cake in the oven at 350°F or heat each serving for 20 seconds in the microwave before serving, or serve chilled. Love the recipe? Leave us stars and a comment below!

review.reviewBody:
I am serving YOUR 'pudding' for my sister's BD which is soon
I am certain she will love it
It brings back memories of when I 
stayed at the Old School House B&B not far from Hobart Tasmania
It had been a school house but now a b&b
They served a lovely meal of Shepherd's Pie and for a 
'sweet' Sticky Chocolate Pudding
much like this ;-)
I had never tried either dish. 
Both exquisite
The unique part of it? The cook prepared this lovely meal for just 
3 of us that evening ;-)

I made this and it came out great. I actually preferred it cold (straight out the fridge) the next day. It was too salty though. I am going to make it again but with less salt. I don't like coffee so just used water and I did not use chocolate chips and found it was sweet and rich enough without. Love it and it is so easy.
I have made this quite often over the past 50 years, however we call it Denver Chocolate Pudding Cake and serve it with sour cream or plain yogurt.

Loved this recipe! Super easy to make and has a great chocolatey texture. The only thing is that I felt it was very sweet, so I would either slightly increase the amount of salt in the recipe or make a note to add flaky sea salt when it comes out of the oven. The texture is very rich and it's wonderful served warm.

I found this in an old recipe book of my mother's back in the 70's. I still make it to this day. It is an excellent dessert but it seems at times the pudding didn't have enough flavor. (don't know why when I always followed the recipe to the letter) but I will most definitely try it with the coffee.
